qas.question: Where is the semiconductor laser found in a CD player?
What wavelenght is used to pull data from a CD?
In what pattern is data stored on a CD?
What is used to discern the change of intensity in light on a CD?
What createds the change in light reflected off of a CD?

answers.text: change in height between pits and lands

qas.question: How long is the swing arm?

plausible_answers.text: the bottom of the polycarbonate layer

qas.question: How many layers of polycarbonate are there?

plausible_answers.text: without having to interrupt the spinning of the disc itself.

qas.question: Why is the data arranged in a spiral pattern?

plausible_answers.text: the way the light is reflected

qas.question: What does the width of a pit indicate?

context: A CD is read by focusing a <a1_0><b5_0>780 nm<b5_0/><a1_0/> wavelength (near infrared) semiconductor laser housed within the CD player, through <b6_0>the bottom of the polycarbonate layer<b6_0/>. The <a4_0>change in height between pits and lands<a4_0/> results in a difference in <b9_0>the way the light is reflected<b9_0/>. By measuring the intensity change with a <a3_0>photodiode<a3_0/>, the data can be read from the disc. In order to accommodate the <a2_0>spiral<a2_0/> pattern of data, the semiconductor laser is placed <a0_0>on a swing arm<a0_0/> <b8_0>within the disc tray<b8_0/> of any CD player. This swing arm allows the laser to read information from the centre to the edge of a disc, <b7_0>without having to interrupt the spinning of the disc itself.
